Subdivision.Name: Basic science
Subdivision.DetailedDescription: The basic sciences of medicine are all about how nature works and about how it interacts with humans. It shows us the basics of medicine, without actually delving into the structures that we usually think of as 'human'. Still, they are some of the most high-value subjects to be studying! Good luck~

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Genetics
DetailedCardInfo.Description: The DNA and RNA that makes us ... us

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Basic genetics
DetailedCardInfo.Description: All about our DNA and how it usually produces protein

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Reproductive genetics
DetailedCardInfo.Description: How we get more of it

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Cell biology
DetailedCardInfo.Description: The biology of our smallest units

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Intracellular biology
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Everything going on within the cell

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Intercellular biology
DetailedCardInfo.Description: BSc. in communication but between cells ... and more challenging

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Extracellular biology
DetailedCardInfo.Description: On cellular products and tissue formation

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Growth and development
DetailedCardInfo.Description: About who we are and where we come from

DetailedCardInfo.Description: Rule 1 of medicine: keep air in the lung

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Nervous system

Subdivision.Name: Applied science
Subdivision.DetailedDescription: The applied sciences make up the bulk of medicine. They describe how the human body is constructed and works. The structures and functions described in the applied sciences form the basis for clinical pathology and disease categories.

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Anatomy
DetailedCardInfo.Description: The structures that determine how we are
DetailedCardInfo.DetailedDescription: Anatomy is the science that describes the structure of the human body. It is essential to be able to not only understand, but also to locate the the source of symptoms.

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Respiratory sytem
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Rule 1 of medicine: keep air in the lung

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Lower airways
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Lungs. Not just one, but two of them!

DetailedCardInfo.Description: Rule 2 of medicine: keep the heart pumping

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Lower urinary tract
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Footballs used to be made from bladder

Subdivision.Name: Clinical science
Subdivision.DetailedDescription: So, then there it is: medicine. Basically, medicine is about the clinical sciences. If you master the art of diagnosis and treatment, you`re on your way to be a great doctor. It`s all about pattern recognition and creative thinking here. You think you`ve got what it takes?

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Diagnoses
DetailedCardInfo.Description: This roughly follows the ICD-11 structure

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Infectious disease
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Diseases caused by bacteria, viruses, fungi or parasites

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Oncology
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Various forms of benign and malign cancer

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Oncology-haematology
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Neoplasms of haematopoietic or lymphoid tissues

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Haematology
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Diseases of the blood or blood-forming organs

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Psychiatry
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Mental, behavioural or neurodevelopmental disorders according to the DSM-V

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Personality disorders
DetailedCardInfo.Description: When it's YOU who is odd

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Somnology
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Conditions preceding, during or following sleep

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Muscular dystrophies
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Kinda what I want to specialise in

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Otolaryngology
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Diseases of the ear or mastoid process

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Supraventricular arrhythmias
DetailedCardInfo.Description: With their origin above the ventricle

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Ventricular arrhythmias
DetailedCardInfo.Description: With their origin in the ventricle

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Pulmonary embolism
DetailedCardInfo.Description: If a clot meets a tiny tube

DetailedCardInfo.Name: (Fatty) liver disease
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Also a large bit about cirrhosis

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Orthopaedics and PM&R
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Diseases of the musculoskeletal system or connective tissue

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Limb fractures
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Just giving it arms and legs

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Perinatal medicine
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Certain conditions originating in the perinatal period

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Hernia diaphragmatica
DetailedCardInfo.Description: A hole in the breathing muscle

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Neural Tube Disorders
DetailedCardInfo.Description: When the neural tube doesn't close

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Toxology
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Injury, poisoning or certain other consequences of external causes

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Treatment
DetailedCardInfo.Description: This roughly follows the ATC system

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Anticoagulants
DetailedCardInfo.Description: When there is stuff you don't want the blood to do

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Antihypertensives and diuretics
DetailedCardInfo.Description: To pee or not to pee, that is the question

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Genito urinary system and sex hormones
Vaccinations (Dutch system)
DetailedCardInfo.Description: The way we do things here

Subdivision.Name: Metascience
Subdivision.DetailedDescription: Here we are: we`ve considered the basics of medicine, the building blocks of the human body and everything that can go wrong with it. Now what about what we should, or shouldn`t do? Or whether we`re actually there ... like, at all? The metasciences teach us all that, and more, probably, I think ... therefore I am.

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Ethics
DetailedCardInfo.Description: The science of what we should and shouldn`t do

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Research methodology
DetailedCardInfo.Description: How we know what we know now, no?

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Medical law
DetailedCardInfo.Description: Limited only to the jurisdiction of the Kingdom of the Netherlands!.

DetailedCardInfo.Description: Page on the basics of wine

DetailedCardInfo.Name: White wine

DetailedCardInfo.Name: Viognier
